awd_titl_txt: WCRP Proposal to NSF for Funding by US Global Chan
awd_abstract_narration: This award provides support for several international activities directed by the International Council for Science that are closely aligned with the strategic goals of the US Global Change Research Program (USGCRP) and with several NSF programs on Global Change Research.  This award will help support US leadership in international science activities and to enable collaborations that are mutually beneficial for US science and international partners in areas of global strategic importance.  These activities will principally focus on two global environmental research activities in the World Climate Research Program.  This program seeks to provide fundamental knowledge about the climate system and to address key challenges in the global environmental  change.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
The NSF grant was instrumental in setting the ground for a long-awaited external independent review of the WCRP programme. The review allowed to assess the effectiveness of the then current structure and governance of WCRP, funding arrangements against evidence collected from the WCRP Secretariat and the WCRP Co-Sponsors (hence also ISC) in relation to past activities.

The review also allowed to assess the effectiveness of the scientific steering committee of WCRP (the “JSC”); the relationship with the Co-Sponsors, as well as between WCRP and other relevant research programmes.

The longstanding support provided by NSF to WCRP through the ISC grant in question since 2014 has allowed WCRP to grow into a research programme which is policy relevant (not policy prescriptive) contributing to major international policy processes and assessment activities, such as the IPCC and the UNFCCC.

The support by NSF over the years ultimately resulted in the current WCRP Implementation Plan and Action Plan, which will run until 2029.

Currently, and also thanks to the NSF support, WCRP is focusing on two high-level research priorities, also referred to as "Implementation Priorities." These are to:

1. Foster and deliver the scientific advances and future technologies required to:

- Advance understanding of the multi-scale dynamics of Earth’s climate system

- Quantify climate risks and opportunities

2. Develop new institutional and scientific approaches required to:

- Co-produce cross-disciplinary regional to local climate information for decision support and adaptation

- Inform and evaluate mitigation strategies
